portfolio.title: My Work
portfolio.pageSubtitle: Building solutions for complex workflows that scale across teams and customers.
portfolio.description: I'm currently helping businesses manage their digital presence @ Yext.

resume.title: My Experience
resume.description: Hi, I’m Ming Ye. A senior UX/UI/Product Designer with a strong background in complex workflow and front-end development. I believe designers are the dot-connectors of the world. We unify not just digital experiences, but also the people behind them to focus on the most impactful outcomes. Currently, I build digital solutions @ Yext to help buisnesses manage their online presence.

about.title: Let's connect!
about.description: Hi, I’m Ming Ye. A senior UX/UI/Product Designer with a strong background in strategic thinking and front-end development. I believe designers are the dot-connectors of the world. We unify not just digital experiences, but also the people behind them to focus on the most impactful outcomes. Currently, I build digital solutions @ Yext. Outside of work, I'm currently learning to do jumping tricks on my snowboard and conquering more V4's at the climbing gym. Whether you are a fellow tech enthusiast or recruiter, I'd love to connect and explore how we might collaborate!

projectData.projectName: Figma Tool for Content and Metadata Annotations & Extraction
projectData.projectDescription: An automated tool to extract content from Figma designs and define metadata for content management.

projectContent.sectionHeading: An Multi-step Figma Tool for extracting Content and Metadata
projectContent.sectionDescription: When building websites, defining page content is only part of the work. Teams must also specify extensive content metadata—such as CTA URLs, media alternative text, and the behavior of interactive components. Historically, this metadata was documented manually by designers and project managers, making the process time-consuming, inconsistent, and error-prone.

blockBulletPoints: I designed and built a Figma-based tool that automates large portions of this metadata definition while intentionally preserving a human validation checkpoint before generating a final, CMS-ready snapshot of the content

infoBlocks.blockDescription: Designers define the page UX, including link behavior (jump vs. external) and accessibility requirements such as ALT text for images and icons.
blockBulletPoints: Because these decisions originate in design, designers typically create and maintain the metadata spreadsheets.
During work-heavy sprints, this manual work often becomes a bottleneck.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: Project managers own timelines and requirements.
blockBulletPoints: They also make final decisions on how page functionality is implemented in development.
They depend on clear, accurate designs and annotations to make those decisions efficiently.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: Developers map metadata fields to page elements and implement the defined behaviors of interactive components.
blockBulletPoints: They need to know what content goes where on each page.
They need to know what functionalities each interactive element has.

projectContent.sectionDescription: Users need to select specific sections to annotate and generate content fields so that shared sections used across multiple pages do not produce duplicate fields.
projectContent.sectionImgAltTxt: Image of Accor metrics grouping table

blockBulletPoints: The tool scans the design to detect sections
Then allows users to choose which sections to extract content from, providing granular control.

projectContent.sectionDescription: Users need to define metadata for page elements so that content fields are accurate, complete, and consistent across the system.

blockBulletPoints: The tool scans elements within a section, identifies content types (e.g., images, icons, links)
Then it automatically generates annotations based on predefined logic, replacing manual work.
To reduce perceived wait time and prevent abandonment, the tool renders annotations progressively and provides real-time status updates.

projectContent.sectionDescription: Users need to review and adjust generated annotations so that metadata fields are accurate before being finalized.

blockBulletPoints: After annotations are generated, users can refine and edit machine-produced annotations directly on the canvas.
To accelerate the clean up, I also added renumbering features that helps quickly identify changes and renumber the annotations.

projectContent.sectionDescription: Users need to generate a structured spreadsheet of metadata fields so that clients can easily input and manage custom content.

blockBulletPoints: The tool generates a reviewable table grouped by section tabs for easy scanning.
Minor copy tweaks are also supported for fine-tuning.
Once finalized, the table can be copied to the clipboard directly and pasted it into existing Google or Excel Sheets.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: The tool reduced manual documentation time by 3 hours.
The tool also established a standardized process for metadata definition across projects.
The output mirrors CMS field structures, enabling faster and more predictable handoff to engineering.

projectData.projectDescription: Help hoteliers of luxury resorts manage their hotels' digital presence through a customized data editing and analytics dashboard.
projectData.projectCoverAltTxt: Project Cover of Accor Hotel Digital Presence Dashboard

projectContent.sectionDescription: Accor is a hospitality group with over 45 brands and 5,600 hotels.
projectContent.sectionImgAltTxt: Image of Accor hotel business overview

blockBulletPoints: Accor uses Yext’s content management system to manage their hotels’ digital presence.
Hotel managers input hotel-specific information to their Yext-powered dashboard.
Next, Yext distributes the information to listing publishers such as Google, Bing, and Apple.

projectContent.sectionImgAltTxt: Image of project goal

blockBulletPoints: The existing dashboard was built to launch quickly. The project team utilized out-of-the-box UI components without any enhancement to meet Accor’s user needs.
Stakeholders voiced that part of the existing dashboard isn't as intuitive as it could be.
With the goal of improving clarity and increasing user engagement, the project team set out to build a new dashboard.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: Users who manage individual hotels.
blockBulletPoints: Knows all of the ins and outs of a specific hotel, including services and amenities offered.
Oversees the hotel restaurants and spas and want to manage the listings of these additional amenities.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: Users who oversee the performance of multiple hotels that fall under the same brand or region.
blockBulletPoints: Prioritizes seeing aggregated performance across regions
Cares about the performance of individual hotels.

projectContent.sectionHeading: What was the problem with existing solution?
projectContent.sectionDescription: We collected user feedback via a short survey to discover existing user pain points. I also conducted a heuristic audit with the goal of simplifying the dashboard for low-tech users. Based on the research, we discovered the following painpoints:

projectContent.sectionImgAltTxt: Image of Accor's old dashboard design

infoBlocks.blockDescription: In the older dashboard, all users, regardless of responsibilities shared the same view. However, not all metrics were equally important to different types of users.
Some hotel managers, especially those less familiar with technology, found the dashboard difficult to navigate. Their feedback revealed confusion about where to look and what key actions to complete.

The ability to filter the dashboard view was scattered across different modules. Each module had its own filtering dropdown (hotel vs. country vs. brand), navigating the scope of data was extremely difficult.

infoBlocks.blockHeading: Not All Fields Are Created Equal
infoBlocks.blockDescription: There are over hundreds of fields that positively impact a hotel’s ranking in search engines. A field can be as specific as whether a hotel has vending machines. Since some fields are more impactful than others (private beach vs. vending machines), users wanted to know which ones to prioritize.
End users were hotel experts but are not SEO experts. They wanted to know how to interpret the information and how it impacted their hotel’s performance.
The field grouping offered a high-level overview of fields. Within each category, user still needed to scan a long list of seemingly-random fields.

projectContent.sectionDescription: For users to access the information they needed quickly, we explored alternative ways to group and filter metrics on the dashboard.
projectContent.sectionImgAltTxt: Image of Accor metrics grouping table

blockBulletPoints: Through a quick logic table exercise, I was able to visualize how the types of available metrics vary across hotel, country, and brand levels.
I conducted whiteboarding session to explore different information architecture for displaying the data: grouping modules by different levels or by metric type.

projectContent.sectionDescription: To help users scan the fields and find the desired ones more quickly, we revamped the field grouping and introduced additional sub-categories to support more granular mental models.
projectContent.sectionImgAltTxt: Image of Accor dashboard's fields grouping excel sheet

blockBulletPoints: When I dove into reorganizing the listing field group, a card-sorting exercise immediately came to mind. However, to ask Hotel managers to take time out of their busy schedules and sort though hundreds of fields seemed unrealistic, so I settled on secondary research.
I compared Accor’s corporate domain, other large hotel chains, and Google My Business listing views to identify ways that other businesses categorized hotel amenities and services.
I studied field definitions to master industry terms and crosschecked grouping logic with AI for additional validation.
With the knowledge, I added tooltip and UX copies to help hoteliers better match each field to their hotels' amentities in the real world.

projectContent.sectionDescription: To promote further actions by the hotel managers to improve hotel's digital performance, we added a net-new "Next Step" module.
projectContent.sectionImgAltTxt: Image of Accor dashboard's Next Step table

blockBulletPoints: I identified 5 distinct next steps and crafted specific UX copies to highlight and distinguish the different messagings.

To ensure each call-to-action is intutive and fitting into the context that it is displayed, I defined the displaying logic behind each message so they only appear in the dashboard view where the related metrics are displayed.

projectContent.sectionDescription: To help users know which fields will have the most impact on their hotel performance, we developed a visual system to communicate different impact levels. We explored three concepts and ultimately chose the second option for its clear messaging, best use of colors, and conciseness.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: The option is straightforward but doesn't visually distinguish the levels from each other.
infoBlocks.blockImgAltTxt: Image of impact indicator in the style of number with text labels

infoBlocks.blockDescription: We picked this option for its clear messaging, best use of colors, and conciseness.
infoBlocks.blockImgAltTxt: Image of impact indicator in the style of color-coded text labels

infoBlocks.blockDescription: Dots alone don’t convey enough meaning, but adding text labels introduces visual clutter.
infoBlocks.blockImgAltTxt: Image of impact indicator in the style of dots with text labels

projectContent.sectionDescription: To help hoteliers better understand how their completion rate, we added a tooltip to establish benchmarks for hotel managers.
projectContent.sectionImgAltTxt: Image of Accor's completion rate design

blockBulletPoints: Color indicators were used for different completion rate ranges to convey urgency.
The tooltip is embeded alongside every occurrence of the completion rate metric to educate users at every opportunity.

projectContent.sectionImgAltTxt: Image of Accor dashboard's redesign

infoBlocks.blockDescription: There are dedicated modules for each distinct type of metric. Filters are consolidated at the top of the dashboard. Users can customize their dashboard view using the filters based on their role and goals all at once.
Carefully crafted tooltips are seen throughout the dashboard to help educate users on what they are looking at and why it is important for them.
Next-step suggestions are provided to guide the users towards impactful actions and improve hotels' online presence.
Fields are reorganized and meticulously grouped into sub-categories to help users find the field are looking for more quickly.
The impact level of each field on their digital performance is added. The color-coded labels help users prioritize which fields to complete.

projectContent.sectionDescription: The initial phase of the project is complete, with positive feedback from end users highlighting its value.

infoBlocks.blockHeading: Putting aggregated data in one place is a very good idea and make it much more readable.
infoBlocks.blockDescription: — Laurance

infoBlocks.blockHeading: Being able to filter by countries and brand is very useful. It would be great to filter by city as well.
infoBlocks.blockDescription: — Maamar

projectContent.sectionDescription: Among the feedback, however, we also recieved request to further enhance the dashboard. These feedback will be addressed in the upcoming product iteractions.
projectContent.sectionImgAltTxt: Image of Accor project's next step

infoBlocks.blockDescription: User feedback revealed that they want to understand the data in the analytic modules, interpret visualizations, and know what actions to take next. Users also expressed interest in seeing more dynamic data and being able to compare changes across longer time periods.
With the improved filtering experience, users are now requesting even more flexibility, such as the ability to manually select a custom subset of hotels to view aggregated performance.

projectData.projectName: Merrill Bank of America Financial Advisor Pages & Dashboard
projectData.projectDescription: Help Merrill's advisors market their services to prospects through landing pages and enhance platform solution that enables advisors to efficiently spin up new team site.
projectData.projectCoverAltTxt: Project Cover of Merrill Bank of America Financial Advisor Pages & Dashboard

projectContent.sectionDescription: Merrill leverages the Yext platform to efficiently manage thousands of financial advisor listings and web pages.
projectContent.sectionImgAltTxt: Image of existing Merrill's digital products

blockBulletPoints: There are three distinct lines of business. Each required tailored branding and specifications.
We had developed a content management dashboard and was looking to build a set of landing page templates for advisor and advisor teams
This solution will showcase each advisor’s financial services while empowering them to effortlessly manage their website content.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: Who are browsing the sites for a perspective advisors or contacting their existing advisors.
blockBulletPoints: Looking for a trustworthy advisor to handle their assets
Learning more about how an advisor or team can support their financial goals

infoBlocks.blockDescription: Who want to market themselves to prospective customers by managing the content on their personal or team sites.
blockBulletPoints: Showcasing their services and capabilities
Connecting with prospects through phone calls, emails, or contact form

projectContent.sectionHeading: How were prospects interacting with the site previously, according to traffic data?
projectContent.sectionImgAltTxt: Image of existing Merrill page's previous analytics

infoBlocks.blockDescription: Scroll analysis revealed that visitors don’t reach 25% of the advisor page, making above-the-fold content critical.
Jumplink navigation recieves the most clicks acorss all interactive elements on the page, indicating that they are a preferred way to navigate the page.
Phone number and address are the most clicked CTAs. "Contact Us" and "Request Appointment" buttons are the second most clicked CTAs, though both lead to similar forms that contain identical fields.

projectContent.sectionHeading: What were the UX issues we identified from the existing experience?
projectContent.sectionImgAltTxt: Image of Merrill's old advisor site design

infoBlocks.blockDescription: Users experienced a few seconds of a blank screen during their first visit. Google PageSpeed Insights confirmed high First Contentful Paint times on both desktop and mobile.
Hero designs featured large images that pushed advisor names and addresses below the fold.
Background images with overlaid text or additional images in multiple sections reduced readability and sometimes obscured advisors' headshots.
It took 8-10 scrolls to reach the bottom of the page. Several text-heavy sections were making the page longer, adding to the page length.
Many advisors had busy schedules and preferred a mix of well-written boilerplate content and customizable sections on their pages
Team portraits can vary in size and aspect ratio, so advisors wanted several hero design options to accommodate these differences.

infoBlocks.blockHeading: Needs multiple ways to feature awards
infoBlocks.blockDescription: Some accolades are awarded to individual advisors, while others are given to the entire team. Advisors wanted to showcase both types of recognition on their pages.

projectContent.sectionHeading: Optimized Layouts to Shorten Page Length
projectContent.sectionDescription: I condensed content by uitilizing tabbed section, expandable dropdowns and carousel on the page to reduce page length.
projectContent.sectionImgAltTxt: Image of condensed sections on Merrill advisor site's redesign

blockBulletPoints: A tabbed section was introduced to organize advisor-specific content such as their investment philosophy and approach into an digestible and interactive format.
A collapsible dropdown was implemented to manage lengthy biography content and maintain a cleaner layout.

projectContent.sectionDescription: I combined the “Contact Us” and “Request Appointment” buttons into a single prominent calls-to-action to streamline prospects outreach.
projectContent.sectionImgAltTxt: Image of above-the-fold section on Merrill advisor site's redesign

blockBulletPoints: The primary button was styled in a distinct color to standout among all interactive elements on the page.
It was also added in the sticky banner to ensure its constant availability as users scroll.

projectContent.sectionDescription: I crafted multiple hero section options for different usecases.
projectContent.sectionImgAltTxt: Image of hero sections on Merrill advisor site's redesign

infoBlocks.blockHeading: Options 1: Full-Width Image vs. Contained Image Layout
infoBlocks.blockDescription: Two layout options are provided. The full-width image layout gives visual prominence to the hero image, creating a bold first impression. The contained image layout puts less spotlight on the advisor image, allowing other content appear higher on the screen.

infoBlocks.blockHeading: Options 2: Dark Background vs. Light Background
infoBlocks.blockDescription: Two color themes are available for the heros to align with different business line brandings. Merrill Wealth Management uses a darker theme, while Private Bank follows a lighter, more minimal visual identity.

projectContent.sectionDescription: I crafted a flexible section layout that can be customized to showcase advisors' accolades. It supports both individual and team awards
projectContent.sectionImgAltTxt: Image of award sections on Merrill advisor site's redesign

blockBulletPoints: Up to 3 individuals can be featured in the section.
Team award layout accommodates images of varying aspect ratios.
Each individual can display up to 10 awards—3 shown by default, with the rest accessible via a dropdown.
Each award can optionally include an award image for added visual interest.

projectContent.sectionDescription: I curated reusable design components that can be used for all templates and breakpoints.
projectContent.sectionImgAltTxt: Image of other sections on Merrill advisor site's redesign

blockBulletPoints: We built a total of 6 templates across three lines of business.

To increase UI and branding consistency across the templates and reduce redundant engineering work, multiple sections were designed as reusable components. These include the blog section, events section, and biography modal.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: Our team successfully launched 15000+ advisors sites at scale in the span of 2 years.
Between Janurary to June in 2025, the site attracted 2.5M page views.
Through the redesign, we achieved a 30% reduction in page length on desktop and 60% on mobile.

projectContent.sectionHeading: Team Site Creation Flow on Content Management Dashboard
projectContent.sectionDescription: The client team requested to implement a site creation wizard, allowing advisors to easily create a new site without external help. Previously, this required contacting Yext Support. The wizard needs to seamlessly fit into the existing dashboard.

infoBlocks.blockImgAltTxt: Icon of team owners or team members
infoBlocks.blockDescription: Advisors who are already in a team but are looking for new partners to form a new team and create a new site.
Advisors who has worked independently but is looking for partners to form a new team and spin up a new site.

projectContent.sectionHeading: What was the desired work flow?
projectContent.sectionImgAltTxt: Flow chart of website creation flow

infoBlocks.blockDescription: To create a team, the team owner has to first find and add other advisor the team.
They then need to provide profile information for that new team, including team name, team owner, and contact information.

After the team creation request is submitted, it goes through an approval process. The approval might take a few days and during this time, advisors can not edit their new team's profile or website. Once the request is approved, a new team and website will be created.
Once a team and its website are created, advisors cannot delete the team themselves. They need to contact Yext support to make the request.

projectContent.sectionDescription: Each step of the workflow is separated into a different screen to reduce cognitive load and help users focus on one task at a time.
projectContent.sectionImgAltTxt: Screen of team creation flow

projectContent.sectionDescription: To reduce errors and support confident decision-making, we added checkpoints and made key actions reversible.
projectContent.sectionImgAltTxt: Screen of team creation confirmation

blockBulletPoints: A confirmation screen was added before a team creation request is submitted
Users will have the option to cancel the action if they want to go back and edit the new team's information.

UnusedProjects.projectDescription: Create 6 website templates that help hundreds of dentists partners maintain their digital presence and create analytics dashboard to help Heartland marketing team improve site and listing performances.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: Managing a dental practice involves numerous responsibilities. Effective marketing is a crucial aspect. However, these non-dental-related tasks can often divert dentists' attention from their primary focus—caring for patients. The project aims to help hundreds of dentists Heartland partners reduce their workload of maintaining their digital presence.

projectContent.sectionDescription: There are multiple stakeholders to consider in the design process, each benefiting from various aspects of the solution:

infoBlocks.blockDescription: who are browsing the sites for a new dentist or booking follow-up visits with their existing providers
who seek greater customization options for content on their sites
who are active managing dentists' listsings and websites

blockBulletPoints: To gain a deeper understanding of business operations, requirements, and goals, participated in multiple requirements sessions with the client team.
I led brainstorming sessions with the client's key contacts to clearly define the problem, identify technical challenges, and develop a comprehensive solution.
I mapped out user flows to visualize the process of launching a new site within the platform.
Using the client-provided design brief, the design team and I created distinct style guides for each template, defining typography and color usage.
I collaborated with developers to dynamically mapping content and color variables to the templates, customizing them for each dental office's branding.
To ensure the templates can work with various branding colors without code change, I created Figma variables to test color application, accessibility, and dark mode functionality.
To highlight data variability to developers while minimizing the number of components, I carefully organized, defined, and reused design components
Developed high-fidelity mockups and implemented a scalable file structure for long-term maintainability.
We successfully launched over 1,700 dentist websites using five of the six available templates.
In 2024, the dental office sites collectively garnered 3.94 million views.
In the same year, the websites generated over 172,000 appointment bookings, indicating that 4.3% of users chose to book an appointment through the site.

UnusedProjects.projectName: Trane Supply Products & Parts Search Site
UnusedProjects.projectDescription: Design an e-commerce search experience that helps field agents and customers efficiently find products or parts to place orders

projectContent.sectionDescription: With millions of products, accessing information was cumbersome. Agents had to navigate multiple databases, manually connecting dots to find details. This project aims to transform the e-commerce site, streamlining part-finding for a seamless shopping experience for HVAC agents and customers.

projectContent.sectionHeading: Who were the users we were trying to help?

infoBlocks.blockDescription: who interact with customers over the phone
who engage with customers in person
or companies who purchase parts from Trane.
who are interested in purchasing parts from Trane

blockBulletPoints: Product information was hosted in separate databases and on different platforms. Agents had to log into multiple platforms and connect the dots manually to find the product they are looking for.
This clunky setup requires an agent to have extensive and percise knowledge of where each piece of data is located and how to find them.
To gain deeper market insights, we also conducted a competitive analysis of direct competitors
We identified common layouts and design patterns across their competitors.
Starting with user stories, the entire project team met to gather business requirements, discuss user needs, business goals, and define the technical details for upcoming features.
Outlined and crafted user flows chart for each user story.
Presented user flows with hifi mockups to shareholders
Collaborated closely with engineers and project managers to define the scope, discuss technical solutions, and identify potential challenges.
As more design mockups are designed, I have regular check-ups with engineers to seek alignment
Led and participated brainstorming sessions
Empowered our four-member design team to address challenging design requests and generate design solutions.
Worked with client's UX researchers to design user feedback questions
Participated in usability study sessions to test out hi-fidelity mockups with end users

infoBlocks.blockDescription: In 2024, our enhanced search platform handled over 9.4 million searches.
To streamline and simplify the product-finding journey, we created a search experience that consolidates related information from multiple databases into a single, cohesive web interface.
Reduced the time it takes for agents and customers to find products parts.

UnusedProjects.projectName: The UPS Store Mircrosite & Search Redesign
UnusedProjects.projectDescription: Revamp the UPS Store Microsite template including the location page, service page and search site to streamline the user experience, minimizing friction in the UI and enhancing navigation.
UnusedProjects.projectProblem: The UPS Store currently hosts its locatiomn microsites on Yext Platform. Each location includes a homepage and a set of location-specific service pages. Although the site has performed steadily over the past few years, The UPS Store is now looking for opportunities to enhance the site and improve the user experience.

blockBulletPoints: Examined the UPS Store search site using heuristic evaluation and web analytics
Conducted user testing on the UPS Store search site
Built audit reports based on the user testing result
Provided design recommendations based on the report insights

infoBlocks.blockHeading: Location Microsite UX Audits & Competitive Analysis
infoBlocks.blockDescription: For the location microsite, our team conducted an in-house competitive analysis. The UPS team also provided us with a third-party heuristic audit.

infoBlocks.blockHeading: Search Site UX Audits & Usability Testing
infoBlocks.blockDescription: For the search site, our team conducted an in-house site analytics, usability testing, and heuristic audit of the search site.

blockBulletPoints: The inbound site navigation is confusing to users. Multiple header links lead to the same page content.
The complete list of services offered at each location is buried lower on the page. As a result, customers have difficulties figuring out whether a location offer a specific service.
The site branding differs significantly from the brand’s main domain UPS.com

The search result only returns information about the current UPS store. This scope of the search, however, is not obvious to users. Customers are searching for non-location-specific information such as store finders or career at UPS
No-result screens are sometimes unhelpful. Search UI would state that filtering to another topic will return a matching result when we know the database doesn’t contain the relevant content.
The lack of search loading indication prompts users to refresh the page, especially at a slower page load speed.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: Based on the data insight, I worked with another designer to devise a redesign plan with the following improvement:
blockBulletPoints: Analyzing search data showed that users typically seek services near their physical location. To accommodate this behavior, we expanded the search scope to display results beyond a single location, prioritizing services closest to the user. We also introduced a 'My Store' button, automatically set to the nearest location, enabling users to refine search results based on their preferred store.
To improve site navigation, we repositioned the breadcrumbs above the header, clearly indicating that the content on the site is specific to the current UPS office.

We revamped the above-the-fold desig  to make accessing services easier. Users can now quickly find relevant services with a single click on the 'Services' Tab without needing to scroll through the entire page.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: I updated the design based on our insights. Our project team then met with the client every week to gather feedback and improve the designs.

blockBulletPoints: Identified key areas for UX improvement on the page.
Built trust with the client by understanding their business needs and design requirements.
